Their law enforcement contacts consisted of minor infractions, arrests that did not lead to conviction, or expunged misdemeanors, none of which provided a legal basis for termination. The complaint alleged that the government's actions, part of a "Student Criminal Alien Initiative," were arbitrary and capricious, exceeded statutory authority, and were carried out without prior notice or an opportunity to be heard, in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. The students sought declaratory and injunctive relief to vacate the terminations and restore their legal status.

The case was assigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White and handled alongside several related cases filed by other students facing the same issue. On April 23, 2025, the students filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) to prevent their arrest or removal. On April 25, 2025, Judge White granted the TRO, temporarily enjoining the government from arresting, incarcerating, or transferring the named plaintiffs, or imposing any other legal consequences based on the SEVIS terminations.

Shortly after the TRO was issued, the government began reinstating the terminated SEVIS records for the plaintiffs and thousands of other affected students nationwide, stating the reinstatements were retroactive. Despite this, on May 22, 2025, Judge White granted the students' motion for a preliminary injunction, extending the protections nationwide to all "similarly situated individuals." The preliminary injunction, reported at *Doe v. Trump*, 2025 WL 1467543, enjoined the government from: (1) arresting, incarcerating, or transferring the students based on the terminations; (2) imposing any adverse legal effects from the terminations; and (3) reversing the SEVIS reinstatements for students maintaining their status for reasons not specified in 8 C.F.R. § 214.1, without prior court approval.

The government filed a notice of appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on July 21, 2025. Subsequently, on August 8, 2025, the government moved to stay the preliminary injunction pending the appeal. On August 22, 2025, Judge White granted the motion in part and denied it in part. The court denied the request to stay the nationwide scope of the injunction and the provision restricting future SEVIS terminations. However, the court modified the injunction's prohibition on arrests and transfers, clarifying that the government is only enjoined from taking such actions based on the original, now-vacated SEVIS terminations, not for new and independent legal reasons. The modified nationwide injunction remains in effect while the appeal is pending.

summary_pairs.summary_A:
On April 7, 2025, the American Foreign Service Association (AFSA), a union representing approximately 18,000 members of the U.S. Foreign Service, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The suit, brought by private and in-house counsel, named as defendants the President, the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), the Department of State, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), and the heads of those agencies in their official capacities.

The case challenges Executive Order 14,251, issued on March 27, 2025. The order invoked a national security provision of the Foreign Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (22 U.S.C. § 4103(b)) to exclude all subdivisions of the State Department and USAID from the statute’s collective bargaining protections. This action effectively eliminated collective bargaining rights for Foreign Service members at those agencies. Following the order, OPM issued implementation guidance, and the State Department terminated its collective bargaining agreement with AFSA, ceased payroll deductions for union dues, revoked official time for union representatives, and ordered AFSA to vacate its government-provided offices.

AFSA alleged that the President's action was *ultra vires* (beyond his legal authority), arguing that the statute only permits the exclusion of specific subdivisions, not the entirety of cabinet-level departments, which it claimed was tantamount to a repeal of the statute by executive fiat. AFSA further alleged that the order was not a bona fide national security determination but was instead unlawful retaliation for the union's public criticism of and litigation against the administration's policies, a violation of its First Amendment rights. As evidence, AFSA pointed to a White House "Fact Sheet" issued with the order that criticized "hostile Federal unions" for obstructing the President's agenda. The union sought declaratory and injunctive relief to nullify the executive order and restore its status and agreements.

AFSA moved for a preliminary injunction. On May 14, 2025, Judge Paul L. Friedman granted the motion (2025 WL 1387331). He found that AFSA was likely to succeed on its claim that the President’s action was *ultra vires*, reasoning that the administration had applied an overly broad interpretation of "national security" that was inconsistent with the statute's purpose. The injunction prohibited the defendants from implementing the executive order and required them to restore AFSA’s recognition as the exclusive bargaining representative and honor all terms of its agreements.

The government appealed the preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit and moved to stay the injunction. After Judge Friedman denied the stay on June 17, 2025, the D.C. Circuit granted the government’s emergency motion for a stay pending appeal on June 20, 2025. The appellate court found that the government was likely to succeed on the merits, that the injunction irreparably harmed the President’s national security prerogatives, and that a stay was in the public interest. The case is related to *National Treasury Employees Union v. Trump*, which challenges a different section of the same executive order.
summary_pairs.summary_B:
Executive Order 14251, issued by President Trump on March 27, 2025, revoked collective bargaining rights for the majority of federal workers, citing “national security” as justification. Section 3 of the Executive Order specifically excluded employees of certain “agency subdivisions” within the Department of State and USAID from the protections of the Foreign Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (FSLMRS). On the same day, the Acting Director of the Office of Personnel Management issued a memorandum guiding departments and agencies on implementing the Executive Order, including identifying which agencies and subdivisions were to be excluded. This lawsuit challenges Executive Order 14251.

On April 7, 2025, the American Foreign Service Association (AFSA), a federal labor union that represents approximately 18,000 foreign service members, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Trump, the Office of Personnel Management, the U.S. Department of State, and the U.S. Agency for International Development. The plaintiffs claimed that the Executive Order exceeded the President's authority, violated the Separation of Powers, and infringed on First Amendment rights. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to bar defendants from enforcing the Executive Order or any accompanying guidance. Judge Paul L. Friedman presides over the case.

The plaintiffs argued that the Executive Order was ultra vires because it effectively repealed the FSLMRS without a valid national security justification, a power reserved for Congress, thereby violating the Separation of Powers. Additionally, the plaintiffs alleged the Executive Order constituted politically motivated retaliation, issued in response to the union's opposition to administration policies. Citing a White House “fact sheet” that described federal unions as “hostile” and at “war” with the President’s agenda, the plaintiffs claimed the Executive Order violated their First Amendment rights and sought to punish the union for defending the nonpartisan integrity of American diplomacy.

On April 14, 2025, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction, arguing that the Executive order caused irreparable harm, including the deprivation of statutory rights to organize and bargain collectively, the loss of 86% of the union’s revenue from dues, the forced return of union officers to regular duties, the potential closure of AFSA’s offices and loss of records, and member confusion over whether union representation remained available. The plaintiffs maintained that an injunction served the public interest, noting that Congress recognized collective bargaining as essential to the effective conduct of public business. The plaintiffs emphasized that preserving the status quo would not harm the defendants, whereas the union and its members would suffer significant injury without relief.

On May 14, 2025, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, blocking implementation of Section 3 of the Executive Order. The court held that the Order was ultra vires and that the union and its members would suffer irreparable harm without an injunction.

On May 21, 2025, the defendants appealed the preliminary injunction to the D.C. Circuit.

On May 22, 2025, the defendants sought an immediate administrative stay and a stay pending appeal of the preliminary injunction. That same day, they also filed a motion for a stay pending appeal in the district court.

The defendants contended that the district court lacked jurisdiction because the Foreign Service Act (FSA) provides the exclusive procedures for labor-management claims, which must be heard by the Foreign Service Labor Relations Board. They maintained that the Executive Order was lawful, as the President has discretion under the FSA to exclude agencies for national security reasons, and that the court erred by failing to defer to this determination. The defendants further argued that the plaintiffs could not demonstrate irreparable harm, noting their ability to collect dues and potential for reimbursement, while the injunction itself harmed the President by restricting his national security prerogatives. Finally, they asserted that the equitable factors overwhelmingly favored a stay, claiming that the district court had usurped a national-security authority statutorily entrusted to the President.

With Judge Friedman unavailable, the motion was referred to Judge Randolph D. Moss. On May 30, 2025, Judge Moss deferred ruling, noting that defendants’ week-long delay in seeking a stay undermined their claims of irreparable harm. He explained that Judge Friedman’s absence and the D.C. Circuit’s expedited consideration made deferral appropriate, though Friedman could revisit the matter upon his return.

On June 17, 2025, Judge Friedman denied the motion for a stay, finding that the defendants had not shown a likelihood of success on appeal. 2025 WL 1695059. The court held that any harm to the defendants was minimal, as the injunction preserved the status quo by maintaining collective bargaining rights established by Congress. While noting that a related D.C. Circuit case, National Treasury Employees Union [../../../../case/46319/], No. 25-5157, recognized potential irreparable harm in a national security context, the court distinguished that case, concluding the defendants had not demonstrated comparable harm here. In contrast, the plaintiffs would suffer “immense and irreparable injury” without an injunction, including disrupted communications with union representatives, loss of official time for union officers, and termination of union dues deductions, all of which impeded the union’s core mission. The court rejected the defendants’ reliance on National Treasury Employees Union, noting that a cited “Frequently Asked Questions” document was inapplicable.

However, on June 20, 2025, the D.C. Circuit granted a stay pending appeal. 2025 WL 1742853. The court reasoned that “foreign affairs are critical to national security,” and that the defendants were likely correct in asserting that the Executive Order was consistent with the Foreign Service Act’s delegation of national-security determinations to the President. The court emphasized that review of such decisions should be highly deferential, since they implicated the President’s core Article II responsibilities. On July 14, the plaintiffs filed a motion for rehearing en banc, which the court denied on July 30.

Back in the district court, on August 4, 2025, the plaintiffs moved for summary judgment.

The case remains ongoing.

summary_pairs.summary_A:
On April 28, 2025, the American Federation of Government Employees and several other labor organizations, nonprofits, and cities/counties filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California. They named President Donald Trump and numerous federal departments and agencies and their agency heads as Defendants. The Plaintiffs challenged Executive Order 14210, which ordered agencies across the federal government to engage in a radical transformation of the federal bureaucracy, including by conducting large-scale Reductions in Force (RIFs), without Congressional authorization. They challenged the executive order and implementing memoranda under the Separation of Powers and the Administrative Procedure Act.

The case was assigned to Judge Susan Illston. On May 1, 2025, plaintiffs filed for a temporary restraining order. After a hearing on May 9, 2025, Judge Illston granted a 14-day temporary restraining order, applicable to the following department:  OMB, OPM, DOGE, USDA, Commerce, Energy, HHS, HUD, Interior, Labor, State, Treasury, Transportation, VA, AmeriCorps, EPA, GSA, NLRB, NSF, SBA, and SSA.  The order paused any further reductions in force and compelled speedy limited discovery.

The government immediately filed an appeal, and sought a stay pending appellate litigation.  The district court declined to enter a stay, and the 9th Circuit set a schedule for briefing to proceed through May 22 (the day before the TRO is set to expire unless extended).  On May 16, the government asked the Supreme Court to grant a stay.

Back in the district court, after briefing, on May 22, 2025, Judge Illston granted a preliminary injunction, barring the challenged government actions during the pendency of the litigation. Following the lead of numerous other courts, Judge Illston rejected the arguement that the agencies were acting of their own accord and were not directed by OMB. Judge Illston held the President would exceed his authority by dismantling programs authorized by Congress. The court reasoned that the dramatic staff reductions will render the agencies unable to do what Congress directs the agencies to do. In light of the evidence, Judge Illston held that the plaintiff's were likely to succeed in their claims that the defendants exceeded their statutory and constitutional authority. American Federation Of Government Employees, AFL-CIO v. Trump, F. Supp. 3d, 2025 WL 1358477 (N.D. Cal. 2025). The government filled an appeal and a motion for a stay pending appeal with the 9th Circuit, on May 23.  (This mooted the request for a stay of the TRO pending before the Supreme Court, so the government withdrew that request.)

On May 30, 2025, the 9th Circuit denied a stay of the preliminary injunction, holding in a published opinion by Circuit Judge William A. Fletcher (joined by Circuit Judge Lucy H. Koh) that  "the government does not 'suffer by a temporary preservation of the status quo,'" and was likely to lose the case. First looking at jurisdiction, the court found that the plaintiffs' claims were not appropriately channeled through the comprehensive administrative system established by the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA), because the CSRA did not give any administrative tribunal the authority to address broad challenges to the defendants' constitutional and statutory authority to direct large-scale federal reorganizations and reductions in force.  On the merits, the court found that neither the Constitution nor any federal statute grants the President the authority to direct the kind of large-scale reorganization of the federal government at issue, noting that the challenged RIFs appear "inextricably intertwined with broad agency reorganization, which the president undoubtedly cannot undertake without Congress." American Federation Of Government Employees, AFL-CIO v. Trump, F. 4th, 2025 WL 1541714 (9th Cir. 2025).  A dissent by Circuit Judge Consuelo M. Callahan countered that Article II of the Constitution vests the President with sufficient authority to cover the challenged conduct.  Judge Callahan dissented that the Executive Order and memorandum merely directed agencies to exercise their own lawful statutory authority and that the district court erred by not finding whether specific RIFs would violate statutory mandates or eliminate agencies.

The government filed a Supreme Court application for a stay on June 2, 2025. The stay application was presented to Justice Kagan. On July 8, the Court granted the stay of the preliminary injunction entered by the United States District Court for the Northern District of California pending the appeal in the United States Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit and the disposition of a petition for a writ of certiorari. The Court reasoned that the executive order and implementing memoranda themselves were likely legal as they only direct agencies to plan reorganizations in force "consistent with applicable law.". The Court declined to express a view on the legality of the Agency RIF or Agency RIF and Reorganization Plan (ARRPs) saying that it was outside the scope of the question in front of them.

Justice Jackson dissented from grant of application for stay. She argued that the Court made this determination outside of the facts and evidence necessary to "responsibly override, reasoned lower court fact-finding." Justice Jackson pointed to the District Court's preliminary findings (which were based "on actual evidence") and argued that the Supreme Court should have declined to intervene. The Court resting the granting of the stay on the merits of the case was inappropriate because the District Court issued an injunction based on the facts collected. She further argued that the executive order and memorandum themselves were unconstitutional executive action that does not "rest on any grant of reorganization authority by Congress."

In response to the stay by the Supreme Court, the plaintiffs asked Judge Illston to reconsider the plaintiffs' request that the government turn over the specific agency proposals for reductions-in-force (RIFs). The government asserted that these documents were protected by the deliberative process privilege. However, Judge Illston rejected this argument, finding that the documents were "likely not pre-decisional and deliberative documents." Judge Illston then ordered the government to respond to the plaintiffs' request by July 14, 2025.

The plaintiffs moved for an order shortening the government's time to respond to the discovery request for the RIFs and AARPs (from the standard 30 days to 14 days). The government responded by saying that all the plaintiffs' claim were APA claims and thus, there is no basis for any discovery in the adjudication of those claims.

On July 15, the government moved for a protective order and/or to quash the plaintiffs' request for production of documents. The motion consisted of seven major claims:

• Discovery is premature because the government still had not responded to the complaint and was planning on moving to dismiss the complaint. The government requested the court rule on the forthcoming motion first before the request for discovery.   • The government reiterated that it would be inappropriate to grant discovery in the adjudication of an APA claim, particularly before an administrative record is certified.   • The requested information is not relevant in light of the stay by the Supreme Court.   • DOGE and United States DOGE services are not agencies that can be sued subject to the APA. The discovery sought against them is without basis.   • The Request for Production (RFP) 1 seeks documents that should be protected by deliberative process privilege.   • The plaintiffs' demand for application for waivers of RIF notice periods and all responses by OMB or OPM to those applications are not relevant to the issues before the court.   • The discovery sought by the plaintiffs is outside the scope of relief the court could grant. The court cannot review the lawfulness of the ARRPs because they are not final agency actions under the APA.

Judge Illston granted this motion in part and denied it in part on July 18. The court reject the government's assertion that the Supreme Court's stay "ends this case" because the stay did not reach several claims in the amended complaint. The Supreme Court's decision did not foreclose considerations of the legality of the ARRPs ("In a concurrence, Justice Sotomayor noted that the Supreme Court's decision allows the district court to consider the legality of the ARRPs in the 'first instance.'") Judge Illston reiterated that a full review of the ARRPs would "significantly aid the Court's review of the merits of these APA claims." Judge Illston rejected the government's argument that the plaintiffs never challenged any of the ARRPs as being arbitrary and capricious. She argued that the defendants are " [arguing] essentially that plaintiffs cannot prove their case because plaintiffs do not have the ARRPs because the ARRPs have not been made public." Judge Illston held that the Ninth Circuit has consistently recognized "narrow exceptions" to the general rule that the reviewal of APA claims are limited to the administrative record. Finally, the court held that even if some material within the ARRPs should be protected by deliberative process privilege, "the need for accurate fact finding overrides the government's interest in non-disclosure."

However, at this point, Judge Illston limited the distribution of the ARRPs to the plaintiffs' counsel and the court. The court also allowed the defendants to redact any material addressing union negotiating strategy to the plaintiffs' counsel. The government was ordered to provide the full version to the court and to highlight any redacted material.

The government filed two motions on July 21: a motion to dismiss and a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction. The government alleged that in light of the Supreme Court's decision, all the plaintiff's claims fail. This is due to the fact that all the claims in the amended complaint "depend on the assertion that the Workforce Executive Order, the Workforce Memorandum, or both are unlawful." Further, the government alleged that to the extent the complaint challenges the ARPs, the ARPs are not final agency actions subject to review under the APA. The government complains that the allegations regarding the RIFs and the ARPs are speculation about future actions the government will take. In regards to the jurisdiction arguments, the government argued that challenges to the lawfulness of federal agency personnel action are precluded from district court review. The government reasserted its claim that the complaint be dismissed as to DOGE which is an initiative and not an agency that can be sued.

On July 21, 2025, the government filed a petition for a writ of mandamus, seeking review of the court's July 18 discovery order. The district court released a statement in response to augment the appellate record. Judge Illston noted that in the government's application for a stay from the Supreme Court, the U.S. Solicitor General represented that 40 RIFs in 17 agencies were in progress and enjoined. However, in response to the discovery order, the petitioners produced a list of those represented RIFs, and numerous agencies that were not defendants in the case (and therefore, not enjoined by the preliminary injunction) were included in the figure presented to the Supreme Court. Judge Illston highlighted that this is no insignificant discrepancy and she reasserted her previous finding that "any deliberative process privilege. . .is overridden by 'the need for accurate fact-finding in this litigation.'"

Judge Illston denied the plaintiffs' request for an order requiring production of the administrative record. The court found that much of the information plaintiffs sought from an administrative record overlapped with other discovery requests that plaintiffs issued and on which the court had already ruled. The court suggested the plaintiffs clarify some of their APA claims to give the government a more "specific understanding of the challenged final agency actions" so that the government can be "expected to produce an administrative record for those actions."

This case is ongoing.
summary_pairs.summary_B:
On April 28, 2025, a coalition of labor unions representing federal employees, non-profit organizations, and local governments filed suit in the Northern District of California challenging President Donald Trump’s Executive Order 14210 and related federal actions. The plaintiffs included national and local unions (such as AFGE, AFSCME, SEIU and their locals), advocacy groups, and the governments of several major cities and counties. The suit was brought against President Trump, multiple federal agencies and their heads—including OMB, OPM, the newly created Department of Government Efficiency (“DOGE”), and major Cabinet departments—and was supported by private counsel and non-profit legal organizations.

The case arose after President Trump issued Executive Order 14210 on February 11, 2025, which initiated what he described as a “critical transformation of the Federal bureaucracy.” The Order directed federal agencies to “promptly undertake preparations to initiate large-scale reductions in force (RIFs), consistent with applicable law,” and to submit to OMB reports discussing whether agencies or their subcomponents should be eliminated or consolidated. The Order prioritized RIFs in any agency function not mandated by statute or law, including offices or programs that the Administration chose to suspend or close, and referenced government shutdown staffing levels as a baseline. The President’s stated goal was to eliminate what he characterized as waste and bloat in the federal workforce, and to reorganize, downsize, or eliminate agencies and functions according to his Administration’s policy priorities, without prior Congressional authorization.

On February 26, 2025, OMB and OPM issued a Memorandum implementing the Order, requiring all agencies to submit Agency RIF and Reorganization Plans (“ARRPs”) in two phases for OMB/OPM review and approval. The Memo required agencies to focus on the “maximum elimination of functions that are not statutorily mandated,” and to achieve significant reductions in staff and operations.

Plaintiffs alleged that the President and his implementing agencies lacked constitutional and statutory authority to undertake or order such government-wide reorganizations and layoffs absent explicit Congressional approval. They contended that these actions usurped Congress’s legislative powers under Article I, violated the separation of powers, and exceeded any authority delegated to the President or agencies under Article II or federal statutes. The Complaint also alleged that OMB, OPM, and DOGE acted ultra vires and that their directives and approvals violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by exceeding statutory authority, engaging in arbitrary and capricious action, and failing to provide notice and comment rulemaking. Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including to enjoin further implementation of the Executive Order, the OMB/OPM Memo, and the ARRPs, and to vacate any actions taken under them.

Judge Susan Illston granted a temporary restraining order on May 9, 2025, and, after further briefing and a hearing, a preliminary injunction on May 22, 2025. The court found that plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims that Executive Order 14210 and its implementation were ultra vires and unconstitutional. The court held that, while the President may set policy priorities, large-scale executive branch reorganization and workforce reductions cannot lawfully occur without Congressional authorization. The court also found that OMB, OPM, and DOGE exceeded their authority by directing agencies to implement the President’s Order, and that their actions likely violated the APA.

The injunction enjoined the President, OMB, OPM, DOGE, and 19 federal agencies (including major Cabinet departments and independent agencies) from taking any actions to implement or enforce Executive Order 14210, the OMB/OPM Memo, or ARRPs, including further approval of plans, issuance or execution of RIF notices, placement of employees on administrative leave, or transfer of functions between agencies. The court also ordered agencies to rescind any RIFs or administrative leave placements issued pursuant to the Order, but stayed that retrospective relief pending appeal. The court required plaintiffs to post a nominal bond of $10.

Defendants appealed and sought an emergency stay in the Ninth Circuit, which was denied. The Ninth Circuit, in a published order, found that defendants had not shown irreparable harm and were not likely to succeed on the merits, holding that the President lacked authority to direct such sweeping reorganization without Congressional approval and that the agencies’ actions exceeded their statutory authority. Judge Callahan dissented, arguing that the claims should have been channeled through the CSRA and that the President’s actions were lawful exercises of executive authority.

At the time of the injunction, the record showed that agencies had begun implementing the Executive Order, including by issuing RIF notices that would have eliminated tens of thousands of positions across multiple agencies, closed entire offices, and transferred or consolidated functions—often without regard to statutory mandates or Congressional funding. The court found that these actions, if not enjoined, would cause irreparable harm to federal employees, unions, local governments, and the public by undermining essential government services and violating the constitutional separation of powers. The case remains pending, with the preliminary injunction in effect and the government’s appeal ongoing.

summary_pairs.summary_A:
This case was a highly unusual federal criminal prosecution of a sitting state court judge—who was alleged by the Trump Administration to have interfered with an immigration arrest. On April 24, 2025, a federal grand jury in the Eastern District of Wisconsin indicted Wisconsin Circuit Judge Hannah Dugan on two counts: (1) obstruction of a federal administrative proceeding under 18 U.S.C. § 1505, and (2) concealment of a person from arrest under 18 U.S.C. § 1071. The case was assigned to U.S. District Judge Lynn Adelman and referred for pretrial matters to Magistrate Judge Nancy Joseph.

According to the indictment, Judge Dugan, while presiding over her courtroom in Milwaukee County Circuit Court on March 14, took steps to prevent U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers' arrest of a noncitizen criminal defendant under an immigration detainer. Federal prosecutors alleged that she challenged the agents’ authority, directed them to speak with the chief judge, resumed the hearing off the record, and permitted the defendant to leave through a secure non-public exit. The government contended that these actions constituted deliberate obstruction of lawful federal enforcement efforts.

Judge Dugan moved to dismiss the indictment on May 14. Represented by former U.S. attorneys and experienced criminal defense counsel, she argued that her alleged conduct was fully within the scope of her judicial duties and was protected by absolute judicial immunity. She contended that the charges violated the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers, the Tenth Amendment’s federalism protections, and the longstanding principle that judicial acts—especially those involving courtroom management—cannot be criminalized. Her briefing drew heavily from Trump v. United States (2024), where the Supreme Court held that the President cannot be prosecuted for official acts, and argued that the same logic applied to judges. She also invoked constitutional avoidance and argued that the relevant criminal statutes could not be construed to reach judicial conduct without raising serious constitutional questions.

Amici curiae briefs were filed on both sides. A coalition of 138 former federal and state judges moved to support dismissal, emphasizing the risk of chilling judicial independence and public trust. They argued that courtroom decision-making must be insulated from criminal sanction, and that accountability for judges is properly handled through appeal or state judicial conduct commissions. In response, the Center for American Rights filed an amicus brief arguing that public officials—judges included—are not immune from prosecution for obstructing justice, and that allowing immunity here would set a dangerous precedent.

On July 7, Magistrate Judge Nancy Joseph issued a Report and Recommendation that recommended that the court deny the motion to dismiss. She concluded that no federal court had recognized absolute judicial immunity as a bar to criminal prosecution, rather than civil liability. While the alleged conduct may have occurred near or within the courtroom, she found that whether it was "judicial in nature" and immune from prosecution was not a question that could be resolved on the pleadings. The Report emphasized that judges have historically been held criminally liable for corruption or obstruction where warranted, citing precedents such as United States v. Claiborne and United States v. Joseph. She recommended that the case proceed to trial, with the motion to dismiss denied in full.

On July 22, Judge Dugan filed objections to the Report and Recommendation, reiterating her constitutional arguments and asserting that the magistrate failed to address controlling authority on judicial independence. On July 29, the government filed its response, urging the district court to adopt the magistrate’s recommendation and allow the case to proceed to trial.

As of August 4, 2025, the district judge had not yet ruled on the motion to dismiss. The case is ongoing.
summary_pairs.summary_B:
On April 24, 2025, federal prosecutors filed criminal charges against a Milwaukee County Circuit Court judge, alleging violations of 18 U.S.C. § 1505 (obstruction of proceedings before a federal agency) and 18 U.S.C. § 1071 (concealing a person to prevent discovery and arrest). The case arises from events on April 18, 2025, when federal immigration agents arrived at the Milwaukee County Courthouse to execute an administrative arrest warrant for an individual scheduled to appear before the judge in a state criminal case. According to the government, after learning of the agents’ presence and their intent to arrest the individual, the judge confronted the agents in the public hallway, asserted that a judicial warrant was required, and directed the agents to leave the area and report to the Chief Judge’s office. While the agents were away, the judge allegedly expedited the court proceedings off the record, then directed the defendant and his attorney to exit through a non-public door, enabling the individual to avoid immediate arrest. The individual was ultimately apprehended after exiting the courthouse.

The United States is represented by the U.S. Attorney’s Office. The judge is represented by private counsel. The matter is not a class action.

The prosecution is based on alleged violations of federal criminal statutes—specifically, obstruction of a federal agency’s proceedings (18 U.S.C. § 1505) and concealing a person to prevent arrest (18 U.S.C. § 1071). The government seeks criminal penalties for these offenses.

After indictment, the judge moved to dismiss the case, arguing that judicial immunity for official acts bars the prosecution, that the Tenth Amendment and principles of federalism preclude federal prosecution of a state judge for judicial acts, and that the statutes should be construed to avoid constitutional concerns. The motion cited longstanding common law and Supreme Court precedents on judicial immunity, and recent Supreme Court decisions on official-acts immunity for executive officials.

The motion to dismiss was referred to Magistrate Judge Nancy Joseph, who issued a detailed report and recommendation on July 7, 2025. Judge Joseph concluded that, while judges are absolutely immune from civil liability for judicial acts, no binding authority extends that immunity to criminal prosecution for official acts, except where Congress has specifically authorized such prosecution (e.g., for civil rights violations under 18 U.S.C. § 242). The magistrate judge found that the indictment alleged conduct—directing agents away, facilitating a defendant’s exit to avoid arrest, and other affirmative acts—that, if proven, could constitute criminal obstruction and concealment, regardless of whether those acts were performed in a judicial capacity. The magistrate judge also rejected the Tenth Amendment and constitutional avoidance arguments, holding that the issues raised were either not appropriate for resolution on a motion to dismiss or unsupported by law.

The judge filed objections to the report and recommendation, reiterating arguments regarding judicial immunity, federalism, and statutory interpretation. The government responded, and on August 26, 2025, District Judge Lynn Adelman adopted the magistrate judge’s recommendation and denied the motion to dismiss.

The case is now proceeding toward trial before Judge Adelman. No trial date has been set as of the latest docket entry. There are no reported opinions beyond the magistrate judge’s report and recommendation (noted at Dkt. 43), and no consolidated or related cases. No settlement, consent decree, or court-appointed monitor is involved.

The underlying factual basis of the case centers on the judge’s alleged actions in response to federal agents’ attempt to arrest a noncitizen defendant at the courthouse, and whether those actions constituted criminal obstruction or concealment under federal law. The legal proceedings to date have focused on threshold questions of judicial immunity and federal authority, with the district court holding that these do not bar prosecution under the facts alleged.

summary_pairs.summary_A:
On April 12, 2025, the ACLU and the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network filed a class-action habeas corpus petition in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado. The petitioners are Venezuelan nationals held in civil immigration detention in Colorado who face summary removal from the United States under a recent presidential proclamation. The respondents are the U.S. government, including the President and officials from the Departments of Homeland Security and Justice.

The case arose after the President, on March 14, 2025, invoked the Alien Enemies Act (AEA) of 1798, a wartime statute, against alleged members of Tren de Aragua (TdA), a Venezuelan criminal gang. The proclamation designated Venezuelan nationals aged 14 and older who are alleged TdA members as "Alien Enemies" subject to immediate apprehension and removal, bypassing standard immigration procedures. The petitioners, who deny any affiliation with TdA, argue that this use of the AEA is unlawful. They contend the proclamation exceeds the statute's authority because a criminal gang is not a "foreign nation or government" and its activities do not constitute an "invasion or predatory incursion" as required by the AEA. They further allege that the summary removal process violates the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and their rights under the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause. The lawsuit followed a U.S. Supreme Court ruling in a related case, *Trump v. J.G.G.*, 2025 WL 102409, which held that challenges to the proclamation must be brought via individual habeas corpus petitions. The petitioners seek a writ of habeas corpus, declaratory judgment, and injunctive relief to prevent their removal under the proclamation.

Filed before Judge Charlotte N. Sweeney, the case saw immediate action. The petitioners filed an emergency motion for a TRO on the same day the case was initiated. On April 22, 2025, Judge Sweeney granted the TRO, provisionally certifying the class and barring the government from transferring class members out of the District of Colorado. The order also required the government to provide 21 days' notice before any removal under the proclamation, with the notice detailing the right to seek judicial review in a language the detainee understands (2025 WL 1163530).

The government immediately appealed the TRO to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit and sought an emergency stay. On April 29, 2025, the Tenth Circuit denied the stay, finding the government had not shown it would suffer irreparable harm (2025 WL 1233583). The government subsequently voluntarily dismissed this initial appeal.

Back in the district court, on May 6, 2025, Judge Sweeney issued two key orders. First, she formally granted the motion for class certification, defining the class as all noncitizens in custody in Colorado who are or will be subject to the proclamation. Second, she granted the petitioners' motion for a preliminary injunction, enjoining the government from detaining, transferring, or removing any class member from the District of Colorado under the authority of the AEA proclamation. The government filed a notice of appeal for both of these orders to the Tenth Circuit on July 7, 2025.
summary_pairs.summary_B:
This is one of several class action challenges to the Trump Administration's use of the Alien Enemies Act ("AEA") to circumvent removal procedures and deport Venezuelan nationals without due process. You can see all of the cases here [../../../../search/case/?advanced_search=true&plaintiff_description=Alien+Enemies+Act&ordering=-summary_approved_date].

On April 12, 2025, two Venezuelan men filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus and a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado. They named as respondents President Donald J. Trump, the Department of Justice, the Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”), the Department of State, and the Denver Contract Detention Facility, the Colorado ICE facility where the petitioners are being held.

Represented by the ACLU, the ACLU of Colorado, and the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network, the petitioners challenged the Administration’s invocation of the AEA to remove them from the United States without any opportunity for a hearing or judicial review. The AEA is a wartime measure that authorizes the removal of citizens from countries with whom the United States is at war. On March 15, 2025, President Trump issued a proclamation declaring that the United States was “under invasion” by Tren de Aragua, a Venezuelan gang and designated foreign terrorist organization, and invoking the AEA.

The petitioners alleged that this use of the AEA violated the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act, and the Fifth Amendment. They sought a writ of habeas corpus releasing them from detention, as well as injunctive and declaratory relief. The case was assigned to District Judge Charlotte Sweeney.

This action was spurred by the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in J.G.G. v. Trump [../../../../case/46232/] that challenges to removals under the AEA must be brought in a habeas petition. The Court in that case vacated a temporary restraining order ("TRO") against removal of the plaintiffs because it found the venue, the District Court for the District of Columbia, to be inappropriate, since habeas petitions should be brought in the district of confinement.

Along with their habeas petition, the petitioners filed an emergency motion for a TRO and a separate motion to certify the class. On April 14, the Court ordered that the petitioners were not to be removed from the United States or the District of Colorado while the case proceeded. The court also set a briefing schedule for the TRO motion and scheduled a hearing for April 21.

Judge Sweeney issued another 14-day TRO following the April 21 hearing, prohibiting the respondents from removing petitioners and class members from the District of Colorado and requiring respondents to give petitioners and class members a 21-day notice if the government sought to detain them pursuant to the AEA. The order also directed petitioner to file any motion for a preliminary injunction (PI) within three days. The court also ordered respondents to respond to the motion for class certification by April 28, with petitioner's reply due by May 2.

Respondents appealed the TRO to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit on April 23 (USCA case no. 25-1164). In the district court, respondents filed an emergency motion for a stay pending appeal, which Judge Sweeney denied on April 24. The same day, the respondent-appellants also filed an emergency stay motion pending appeal in the Tenth Circuit, which ordered petitioner-appellee to respond by April 26, with any reply due by April 27. The Court of Appeals denied the emergency stay motion on April 29, finding that the government had not made the required irreparable-injury showing.

The petitioner filed a motion for a preliminary injunction (PI) on April 25. The respondents filed their response five days later, and petitioner filed his response on May 2.

Briefing on the class certification motion took place according to the court's schedule included in its order granting the TRO, concluding on May 2.

On May 6, Judge Sweeney certified a class of "All noncitizens in custody in the District of Colorado who were, are, or will be subject to the March 2025 Presidential Proclamation entitled 'Invocation of the Alien Enemies Act Regarding the Invasion of the United States by Tren de Aragua' and/or its implementation."

Judge Sweeney examined closely each of the requirements for certifying a class, holding most importantly that the class members' risk of deportation under the Proclamation provided the required commonality. She rejected arguments that differences in other parts of class members' cases should prevent certification. She also certified the class under Rule 23(b)(2) finding that the proposed class was “sufficiently cohesive,” and that the injunctive relief the petitioners sought “would benefit them as well as all members of the proposed class in the same fashion.”

Judge Sweeney also entered a preliminary injunction ordering the government not to detain, transfer, or remove petitioners and members of the certified class from the District of Colorado.

Judge Sweeney found that petitioners were likely to succeed on the merits because a “invasion” under the AEA demands military action by a foreign nation government.  She held that the Proclamation fails to adequately find or assert TdA was a foreign nation or government. Judge Sweeney accepted the petitioners' allegations that they faced the risk of irreparable harm in part because of the detention conditions in El Salvador’s Terrorism Confinement Center (CECOT).  In balancing the equities and public interest, Judge Sweeney found that the public interest in preventing wrongful removals—particularly where those removals exposed Petitioners and class members to harmful conditions—outweighed any harm to the government, partly because any such harm was mitigated by the government's availability to prosecute and remove noncitizens under Title 8,

In reaching this decision, Judge Sweeney rejected the government's argument that the petitioners lack standing because they were not at the time of the hearing designated as falling under the Proclamation. Judge Sweeney concluded “there is a  substantial risk that the harm of being subject to the Proclamation will arise—despite [Petitioners’] current designation as individuals who do not fall under it.”

Judge Sweeney also rejected respondents' broad challenges to jurisdiction on the basis that the petition constituted an unconstitutional challenge to presidential power, the political question doctrine, and several other broad attacks on the court's jurisdiction.

On July 7, the government appealed the injunction and class certification to the U.S. Circuit Court for the Tenth Circuit (Case No. 25-1265).

This case is ongoing.

summary_pairs.summary_A:
This is one of several challenges to the Trump Administration's use of the Alien Enemies Act ("AEA") to circumvent removal procedures and deport Venezuelan nationals without due process. You can see all of the cases here [../../../../search/case/?advanced_search=true&plaintiff_description=Alien+Enemies+Act&ordering=-summary_approved_date].

On April 8, 2025, two Venezuelan men filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. They named as respondents President Donald J. Trump, the Department of Justice, the Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”), the Department of State, and the Orange County Correctional Facility, a county prison in New York that contracts with ICE where the petitioners are being held.

Represented by the ACLU, the petitioners challenged the Administration’s invocation of the AEA to remove them from the United States without any opportunity for a hearing or judicial review. The AEA is a wartime measure that authorizes the removal of citizens from countries with whom the United States is at war. On March 15, 2025, President Trump issued a proclamation declaring that the United States was “under invasion” by Tren de Aragua, a Venezuelan gang and designated foreign terrorist organization, and invoking the AEA.

The petitioners alleged that this use of the AEA violated the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act, and the Fifth Amendment. They sought a writ of habeas corpus releasing them from detention, as well as injunctive and declaratory relief. The case was assigned to Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein.

This action was spurred by the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in J.G.G. v. Trump [../../../../case/46232/] that challenges to removals under the AEA must be brought in a habeas petition. The Court in that case vacated a temporary restraining order ("TRO") against removal of the plaintiffs because it found the venue, the District Court for the District of Columbia, to be inappropriate, since habeas petitions should be brought in the district of confinement.

Along with their habeas petition, the petitioners also filed an emergency motion for a TRO and a separate motion to certify the class. The same day the Court ordered that the petitioners were not to be removed from the United States or the Southern District of New York while the case proceeded. A hearing was held on April 9, after which the court issued a TRO. The court converted the plaintiffs' TRO motion to a motion for a preliminary injunction (PI) and ordered the respondents to file their response by April 15, with a hearing on the PI motion scheduled for April 22.

Also on April 9, the Court granted the petitioners' request for class certification. The petitioners filed a request for modification of the class certification on April 10, asking the court to amend the definition of the certified class by "removing the requirement that class members be in the custody of the United States, to ensure that the class includes individuals subject to the Presidential Proclamation who are in state or local custody." The court made the requested modification on April 11 and also amended the TRO to reflect the new class definition.

The respondents filed a motion to decertify the class on April 21, arguing that the court lacked jurisdiction to review and enjoin the federal government's activities at issue in this case; namely, the President's exercise of authority under the AEA.

Following the April 22 hearing on the PI motion, the court extended the TRO until the court ruled on the PI motion.

On May 6, Judge Hellerstein granted the petitioners motion for a preliminary injunction and enjoined the government from the following:

Enforcing, in the Southern District of New York, Presidential Proclamation No. 10903, 90 Fed. Reg. 13,033 (2025) entitled "Invocation of the Alien Enemies Act Regarding the Invasion of the United States by Tren De Aragua," and are thus prohibited from, inter alia, removing Petitioners, including members of the Certified Class, from the United States, under authority of said Presidential Proclamation.

Judge Hellerstein also ordered the government not to transfer Petitioners including the members of the Certified Class from the Southern District of New York.

In the same hearing, Judge Hellerstein denied the government's April 21 motion to decertify the class, noting:

Here, it is not known how many people in the jurisdiction of this Court may become subject to an order of removal. The issues resolved in this case may have to be resolved over and again as the government removal policy continues. Judicial efficiency, and considerations of due process for individuals yet to be ordered to be removed, support a class action. Moreover, . . . many of the Class members cannot speak English, do not have easy access to counsel, and share common questions.

On July 9, the government appealed the class certification and preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit (Case No. 25-1671).

This case is ongoing.
summary_pairs.summary_B:
This case was filed on April 8, 2025, in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by a group of Venezuelan men in immigration custody, represented by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the New York Civil Liberties Union, both private non-profit legal organizations. The suit is a class action brought on behalf of all noncitizens in federal, state, or local custody in the Southern District of New York who are or will be subject to a March 2025 Presidential Proclamation invoking the Alien Enemies Act (AEA), and who have not received notice and a hearing as required by recent Supreme Court precedent.

The respondents include the President of the United States, the Attorney General, the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of State, various federal immigration officials, and the director of the Orange County Correctional Facility. The case is presided over by Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein.

The plaintiffs challenge the lawfulness of the Presidential Proclamation signed on March 14, 2025, which invoked the Alien Enemies Act, 50 U.S.C. §§ 21-24, to authorize the immediate removal of Venezuelan nationals alleged to be members of the Tren de Aragua (TdA) gang. The Proclamation characterized TdA as perpetrating an “invasion or predatory incursion” into the United States, thereby triggering the AEA’s provisions. Under the government’s implementation, individuals identified as TdA members, often based on physical characteristics or minimal evidence, were subject to summary removal without individualized notice or an opportunity to contest their designation. Many were removed to a prison in El Salvador, where, according to the plaintiffs, they faced indefinite detention and the risk of torture or inhumane conditions.

The plaintiffs assert causes of action under the AEA, the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Convention Against Torture (as implemented by FARRA), the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause, and the Suspension Clause. They seek a writ of habeas corpus, declaratory and injunctive relief, and class certification. Specifically, they argue that the AEA was unlawfully invoked in the absence of a declared war or genuine invasion by a foreign nation, that the Proclamation violates statutory and constitutional guarantees of due process, and that it bypasses protections for asylum seekers and those fearing persecution or torture.

On April 9, 2025, Judge Hellerstein granted a temporary restraining order, enjoining the government from removing or transferring class members under the Proclamation without notice and a hearing. The class was certified as all noncitizens in federal, state, or local custody in the Southern District of New York subject to the Proclamation and lacking required notice and hearing, with notice to be provided in English and Spanish. The TRO was later amended and extended, and the class definition was broadened to include those in state or local custody.

On May 6, 2025, following briefing and a hearing, Judge Hellerstein issued a preliminary injunction. The court found that the AEA does not authorize removal absent a declared war or true invasion/predatory incursion by a foreign nation or government, and that the Proclamation’s characterization of criminal activity by a gang did not meet this statutory threshold. The court further held that the Proclamation and its implementation violated both the procedural requirements of the AEA and the Due Process Clause, as individuals were not given adequate notice or a meaningful opportunity to contest their designation as “alien enemies.” The injunction enjoined enforcement of the Proclamation in the Southern District of New York and prohibited the removal or transfer of class members under its authority, except as permitted by regular immigration proceedings under the INA. The court did not require the plaintiffs to post a security bond.

The government’s subsequent motion to decertify the class was denied, with the court emphasizing the appropriateness of class-wide habeas relief given the common legal and factual issues and the practical barriers faced by class members. The preliminary injunction remains in effect pending further proceedings or appeal. On July 3, 2025, the government filed a notice of interlocutory appeal, and further district court proceedings have been stayed pending appellate review.

No trial has occurred, and the case has not reached a final judgment. Significant related cases include the Supreme Court’s decision in Trump v. J.G.G., 145 S. Ct. 1003 (2025), which clarified the procedural rights of detainees under the AEA and established the requirement for notice and an opportunity to seek habeas relief before removal. No court-appointed monitor has been designated, and there is no settlement or consent decree in place. The case remains in active litigation, with the preliminary injunction as the operative court order.

summary_pairs.summary_A:
On April 4, 2025, enrolled members of the Blackfeet Nation filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Montana against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, its Secretary, and the United States of America. The plaintiffs, who include a rancher, a state senator, and operators of a cross-border tourism business, challenge a series of executive orders and proclamations issued in early 2025 that imposed significant tariffs on goods imported from Canada.

The lawsuit alleges that the tariffs, justified by the executive branch under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) and Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, are unconstitutional. The plaintiffs claim the executive actions usurp Congress's exclusive authority to regulate commerce and impose tariffs under Article I of the Constitution. They also assert that the tariffs violate their rights under the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and their historic, treaty-protected right to trade and travel across the U.S.-Canada border without duties, as recognized in the Jay Treaty of 1794. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, seek declaratory and injunctive relief to block the enforcement of the tariffs.

The federal defendants responded by filing a motion to transfer the case, arguing that the U.S. Court of International Trade (CIT) has exclusive jurisdiction over matters concerning tariffs and international trade law. On April 25, 2025, Judge Dana L. Christensen granted the motion, finding that the plaintiffs' claims fell squarely within the CIT's exclusive jurisdictional grant under 28 U.S.C. § 1581(i). The court determined that challenges to tariffs imposed under the IEEPA and Section 232, as well as claims arising from the Jay Treaty, must be heard by the CIT to ensure national uniformity in trade law. The court vacated a scheduled hearing on the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.

The plaintiffs immediately filed a notice of appeal of the transfer order to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The district court subsequently denied the plaintiffs' motion for an injunction pending appeal, ruling it no longer had jurisdiction over the matter. The plaintiffs also filed a motion for reconsideration of the transfer order. On June 2, 2025, Judge Christensen denied the motion for reconsideration, reaffirming the finding of exclusive CIT jurisdiction and noting that the CIT itself had asserted jurisdiction in similar tariff-related cases. The appeal of the transfer order remains pending before the Ninth Circuit.
summary_pairs.summary_B:
This case raises urgent questions about the scope of presidential authority over trade and the constitutional rights of Indigenous communities living along the U.S.–Canada border. On April 4, 2025, two members of the Blackfeet Nation—Montana State Senator Susan Webber and rancher Jonathan St. Goddard—filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Montana against the United States, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS), and DHS Secretary Kristi Noem, in her official capacity. Represented by private counsel, plaintiffs challenged a series of executive actions issued by President Donald Trump that imposed tariffs on goods entering from Canada. The plaintiffs argue that the tariffs unlawfully burden commerce and travel essential to Blackfeet citizens and violate longstanding treaty protections and constitutional guarantees.

The challenged actions include multiple executive orders and proclamations—collectively referred to as the “Canada Orders.” These include: (1) Executive Order 14193 (Feb. 1, 2025), which declared a national emergency and imposed tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA); (2) Proclamations 10895 and 10896, which levied 25% tariffs on aluminum and steel under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act; and (3) Executive Order 14257 (Apr. 2, 2025), which introduced reciprocal tariffs to counter perceived trade imbalances. Plaintiffs claim these measures, which apply universally without exemptions for Indigenous trade, violate constitutional principles and federal treaties.

The plaintiffs assert multiple legal theories. First, they argue that the President lacked statutory authority to impose tariffs of this scale and scope. Specifically, they contend that IEEPA does not authorize universal tariffs unrelated to a clear foreign threat and that the Trade Expansion Act's delegation of power under Section 232 cannot justify these broad economic measures. Second, they allege that the executive actions violate the separation of powers by encroaching on Congress’s exclusive authority over foreign commerce under Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution.

In addition to constitutional structure, the plaintiffs raise claims under the Due Process Clause. They argue that the tariffs impose arbitrary and sweeping economic burdens without procedural safeguards or individualized assessment. The complaint also references historical protections under the Jay Treaty of 1794, the Treaty of Ghent (1814), and early federal tariff acts that explicitly exempted Indigenous trade from duties. The plaintiffs maintain that these protections remain valid, self-executing treaty rights that predate and override later conflicting executive actions.

To support their claims, the plaintiffs filed declarations and affidavits documenting the concrete harms caused by the tariffs. These include rising business costs, lost tourism income, and disrupted family and trade relations across the northern border. In particular, Senator Webber emphasized the disproportionate impact on the Blackfeet Nation, whose homelands, commerce, and kinship networks span both sides of the U.S.–Canada border.

Plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief. Specifically, they asked the Court to declare key portions of the Canada Orders unconstitutional, enjoin their enforcement, and, alternatively, exempt tribally enrolled members or tribal border crossings from the tariffs. They also sought attorneys’ fees and any other relief deemed just and proper.

This case was assigned to U.S. District Judge Dana L. Christensen. On April 4, 2025, Plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary and permanent injunction. On April 11, they filed an amended complaint adding four additional plaintiffs: Ryan Biederman, Andrea Bocanegra, David Greer, and Lisa Ruelas. On April 14, the government moved to transfer the case to the U.S. Court of International Trade and requested a stay of proceedings pending that decision. Plaintiffs opposed both motions, arguing that their constitutional and treaty-based claims require resolution in a federal district court with jurisdiction over constitutional and equitable claims.

On April 21, 2025, the Montana Farmers Union (MFU) moved the court to intervene as a party-plaintiff.

On April 25, 2025, the court granted the defendants' motion to transfer the case to the U.S. Court of International Trade and denied their motion to stay as moot. Plaintiffs immediately appealed the transfer order to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and filed a motion in the district court for a preliminary injunction pending appeal. On April 28, plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the transfer order. That same day, the district court denied their request for a preliminary injunction pending appeal.

In the Court of Appeals, plaintiff-appellants filed a motion for injunctive relief on May 1, 2025. Defendant-appellees filed a motion to dismiss that same day. On May 23, the court denied the motion to dismiss without prejudice and ordered that all appellate proceedings, except for mediation, be stayed pending the district court's ruling on the timely tolling motion filed on April 28, 2025.

On June 2, the district court denied plaintiffs' motion for reconsideration. Following this, plaintiffs filed a motion to expedite in the Court of Appeals, arguing that the stay previously entered was moot in light of the district court's ruling. They requested that the Court of Appeals set an expedited briefing schedule on the merits of their appeal and grant their fully briefed motion for a preliminary injunction. The motion for an expedited briefing schedule was granted on June 18.

This case is ongoing.

summary_pairs.summary_A:
This case challenged the Trump Administration’s actions to limit the Social Security Administration’s ability to serve people with disabilities under the guise of bureaucratic “efficiency.” On April 2, 2025, plaintiffs—American Association of People with Disabilities, National Federation of the Blind, DEAF Equality, National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare, Massachusetts Senior Action Council, and private individuals—filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. Judge Amit Priyavadan Mehta was assigned to the case. Plaintiffs sued the Social Security Administration (SSA), the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), Elon Musk, and other acting heads of these administrative agencies. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to halt widespread service disruptions and the elimination of legally required civil rights protections.

Plaintiffs claimed that defendants’ abrupt dismantling of SSA’s operations caused irreparable harm to millions of disabled and elderly beneficiaries. They alleged that between January and March 2025, defendants orchestrated a sweeping rollback of services: eliminating the Office of Civil Rights and Equal Opportunity (OCREO), terminating the Office of Transformation, cutting 7,000 SSA employees, freezing hiring, and closing field offices. These changes, they argued, were ordered or heavily influenced by DOGE, a new federal entity created by Executive Order No. 14158, 90 Fed. Reg. 8441 (Jan. 29, 2025).

Executive Order 14158 established DOGE to "modernize federal technology and software" and to "maximize governmental efficiency." It embedded DOGE teams within federal agencies and granted them sweeping access to internal operations and data. Plaintiffs argued that DOGE’s directives had resulted in massive breakdowns in SSA’s ability to deliver benefits, such as multi-hour phone hold times, crashed websites, inaccessible field offices, and termination of benefits for vulnerable individuals.

Plaintiffs filed their complaint on April 2, 2025, alleging defendants’ actions violated the Rehabilitation Act for discriminatory removal of accommodations and civil rights protections. They also asserted APA violations for arbitrary and capricious restructuring without statutory authority and not in accordance with law. Additionally, plaintiffs asserted a First Amendment challenge, arguing that defendants' dissolution of OCREO—the SSA grievance system—unconstitutionally deprived them of their right to petition for redress. Finally, they argued that defendants violated the Take Care and Due Process clauses. Plaintiffs sought a preliminary and permanent injunction barring further implementation of the DOGE-imposed reforms, restoration of OCREO and the Office of Transformation, reinstatement of staffing and telephone services, and court monitoring of SSA compliance. They also requested that the court declare the defendants’ actions unlawful and unconstitutional.

On the same day, plaintiffs filed a separate motion for a preliminary injunction to stop the elimination of OCREA and the Office of Transformation within SSA, the revocation of the SSA offices, and the mass termination of SSA employees, and to roll back recent policies that increase applicants’ and beneficiaries’ need to seek services in person. Defendants filed their opposition to the preliminary injunction motion on April 16, arguing that (1) plaintiffs lacked standing, (2) the court did not have subject matter jurisdiction, and (3) their claims would fail on the merits. Plaintiffs responded on April 21, 2025, refuting all of defendants' arguments.

On April 9, 2025, an unopposed motion for leave to file an amicus brief in support of plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction was filed by the Center for Medicare Advocacy and Medicare Rights. In their brief, amici argued that disruption to the SSA system had negative effects on Medicare recipients, which disproportionately impacted disabled individuals. On April 15, amici---the States of Connecticut, Arizona, California, Colorado, Delaware, Hawai'i, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Nevada, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, Washington, and the District of Columbia by state of Connecticut---also filed a brief in support of plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction.

On May 6, 2025, the court denied the motion for preliminary injunction, determining plaintiffs failed to establish irreparable harm. The court found that individual plaintiffs could not demonstrate "life [or] death" circumstances, and that plaintiff organizations could not prove in sufficient detail that they or their members were "perceptibly impaired" by defendants' actions.

The court has set a briefing schedule. Defendants will file their motion to dismiss by August 8, 2025. Plaintiffs' response brief in opposition to that motion will be due September 12, and defendants' reply will be due September 26. The court will rule on the motion to dismiss after that date.

This case is ongoing.
summary_pairs.summary_B:
On April 2, 2025, a lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by several disability rights organizations (including groups representing people with disabilities, the blind, the deaf, and seniors) and seven individual plaintiffs who are disabled older adults and individuals. The plaintiffs sued the Social Security Administration (SSA), its Acting Commissioner, the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), its Acting Administrator, and Elon Musk in his official capacity as the de facto head of DOGE. The plaintiffs are represented by private law firms and legal services organizations.

The factual basis of the case stems from recent administrative reforms at the SSA, initiated by its Acting Commissioner under the direction of DOGE. These reforms included the elimination of two key SSA offices: the Office of Civil Rights and Equal Opportunity (OCREO), responsible for discrimination complaints and reasonable accommodation requests, and the Office of Transformation (OT), tasked with modernizing customer service and digital infrastructure. Additionally, the SSA announced a plan to reduce its workforce by 7,000 employees, consolidate regional offices, and initially implement new identity verification policies that would increase the need for in-person visits to field offices. The plaintiffs allege these actions constitute an "unprecedented and unconstitutional assault" on Social Security benefits, severely undermining the agency's public-facing services and causing significant delays in application processing, hindering access to critical accommodations, and dismantling civil rights protections. They contend these changes disproportionately harm people with disabilities and older adults who rely on SSA for essential benefits.

The plaintiffs brought claims alleging violations of Section 504(a) of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794(a)), which prohibits disability-based discrimination; the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause; the First Amendment's Right to Petition the Government; and multiple provisions of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) (5 U.S.C. §§ 702–06). Under the APA, they specifically alleged unlawfully withheld or unreasonably delayed agency action, arbitrary and capricious agency action, action not in accordance with law (including violations of the Federal Vacancies Reform Act and the Appointments Clause of the U.S. Constitution), and action in excess of statutory authority.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory judgment and injunctive relief, specifically requesting a preliminary and permanent injunction to halt the alleged unlawful actions. The requested injunction aimed to prevent further dismantling of OCREO and OT, stop the termination and require the rehiring of the 7,000 staff, enjoin the closure of SSA offices, and reverse new policies requiring in-person identity verification. They also sought reasonable attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses.

The case was assigned to Judge Amit P. Mehta. On April 2, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a Motion for a Preliminary Injunction. Amicus briefs in support of the plaintiffs' motion were filed by the Center for Medicare Advocacy and Medicare Rights Center on April 10, 2025, and by the States of Connecticut and twenty other states and the District of Columbia on April 15, 2025. Defendants filed their opposition to the preliminary injunction on April 16, 2025, arguing, among other things, that plaintiffs lacked standing and that federal personnel statutes precluded judicial review of employment-related claims, citing *OPM v. AFGE, No. 24A904, 2025 WL 1035208 (S. Ct. Apr. 8, 2025)*. Plaintiffs filed a reply in support of their motion on April 21, 2025.

On May 6, 2025, Judge Mehta issued a Memorandum Opinion and Order denying the plaintiffs' Motion for a Preliminary Injunction. The court found that the plaintiffs failed to meet the "high standard" of establishing irreparable harm, noting that individual plaintiffs largely complained about issues predating the challenged administrative actions or failed to demonstrate a "certain and great" near-term life-or-death consequence. Similarly, organizational plaintiffs did not provide sufficient specifics to show a "perceptible impairment" of their programs or a "direct conflict" with their mission.

Subsequently, on June 20, 2025, the defendants filed a Motion to Dismiss the plaintiffs' complaint. However, on July 7, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an Amended Complaint. As a result, on July 8, 2025, Judge Mehta denied the defendants' Motion to Dismiss as moot, without prejudice, due to the filing of the amended complaint. A suggestion of death was filed on June 11, 2025, for plaintiff Treva Olivero.

summary_pairs.summary_A:
This case challenged Executive Order 14248, which imposed various requirements on federal elections. On April 3, 2025, nineteen states filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, naming President Donald Trump, the U.S. Attorney General, the U.S. Election Assistance Commission (EAC) and its director and commissioners, and the Secretary of Defense as Defendants. They challenged multiple sections of Executive Order 14248, titled "Preserving and Protecting the Integrity of American Elections," signed on March 25, 2025. These sections:

• Require the EAC to demand documentary proof of citizenship and to record such information,   • Require the heads of federal voter registration agencies to assess citizenship prior to providing registration forms,   • Order the Secretary of Defense to require proof of citizenship in the Federal Post Card Application,   • Command the Attorney General to take action against states that count absentee ballots received after Election Day, and   • Condition federal funding upon compliance with the EO.

The plaintiffs alleged that by purporting to impose election rules on the states, the President exceeded his constitutional powers and unlawfully infringed on congressional and state authority, thereby violating the Separation of Powers, the Administrative Procedure Act, the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA), and the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act (UOCAVA). Represented by their respective attorneys general, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as attorney fees. The case was assigned to District Judge Denise J. Casper.

On April 23, the defendants moved to transfer and consolidate this case with a case in the District Court for the District of Columbia, League of United Latin American Citizens v. Executive Office of the President [../../../../case/46322/], which also challenged the EO. Judge Casper denied the motion on May 9, finding that transfer was not in the interests of justice in this case, given that the plaintiffs here were states, not private parties, and this case challenged different sections of the EO from those challenged in the D.D.C. case.

On May 5, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. The court granted the motion on June 13, finding that the challenged sections were ripe for review since they either imposed deadlines or clearly laid out actions that the defendants were required to take.
